questions.text: A 30-year-old male has presented to you with intense watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. He took out his contact lens and applied eye lubricants to help alleviate his ailment, but it didn’t provide any relief. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Giant papillary conjunctivitis 
The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Refractive correction
The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction. Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glasses Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis along with mild ptosis as shown in the below image. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing Fasanella-Servat operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Muller’s muscle

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner’s syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller’s muscle.

questions.text: A man with known history of diabetes has come to your clinic. His vision is 6/6. However, on retinal examination, he is classified to have severe NPDR. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Disc neovascularisation 
Disc neovascularization is not a feature of nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), and is seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2 weeks
In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, the infant must be screened in 2 weeks (i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age) as per the guidelines for the management of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rhabdornyosarcoma
The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of protrusion of eye with well-defined mass in the orbit and adjacent bony destruction on CT scan and biopsy showing small, round cells positive for Desmin favors rhabdomyosarcoma.
Cavernous hemangioma(option B) and orbital cellulitis(option C) usually are associated with fever, hence ruled out. Retinoblastoma (option A) is associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on microscopy, therefore its not correct.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner Winterstein rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Retinoblastoma
The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner Winterstein rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyperopia
Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia). It might result due to increased accommodative effort in cases where there is under correction of hypermetropia. The condition may be prevented by full hypermetropic correction.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with hypertension has silver wiring, papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy, but no other changes. How would you grade his disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Grade IV retinopathy

A patient with hypertension has “silver wiring,” papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visible on fundoscopy but no other changes would be classified as having Grade IV retinopathy.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pan-retinal photocoagulation
The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.
Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ptosis
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and Ptosis is the most common ocular feature of the disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis and enophthalmos. On examination, the ciliospinal reflex is found to be absent. The treatment of choice for correction of ptosis in the above patient would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fasanella servat operation
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Horner’s syndrome. Fasanella servat is the treatment of choice for mild ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome. Fasanella servat operation is done for cases of mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) with retained levator palpabrae superioris muscle function as seen in Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes for an ophthalmological examination. She says she is unable to thread a needle and is facing difficulty making a sweater for her grandson. She never had vision problems in her youth. What is false here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopla. It requires convex glasses for near work

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination, the eye is white and there are по obvious signs on ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Retrobulbar neuritis
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis.

questions.text: A mother asks for LASIK surgery for the correction of her 15-year-old daughter’s myopia. Which of the following is not an eligibility criterion for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Age of 15 years 
Age of 15 years is not a criterion for LASIK surgery. LASIK surgery is performed after 18 years of age.

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The image shows inflammation and hypopyon. These signs, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis. The management is to administer intravitreal antibiotics.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents at the optician's shop for a change of her presbyopic glasses. This is the third time that she is coming in 2 months. The optician is worried about this frequent change and refers her to the ophthalmologist. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Open-angle glaucoma 

Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses is a symptom of open-angle glaucoma (OAG). It is due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and nerve supply

questions.text: During a community outreach program in a rural area, you come across a girl with a conjunctival lesion as shown in the image. According to the WHO grading, which grade does this child falls under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given image shows Bitot's spot, which is seen in the X1B stage of vitamin A deficiency.
The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.
The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.
The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

questions.text: A term neonate is referred to the district hospital for an ophthalmic exam. Partial fusion of her right upper and lower eyelids by a central narrow band of tissue is noted as shown below. The left eye examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ankyloblepharon, adhesion between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids. It may occur as a congenital anomaly or as acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, ulcers, or traumatic wounds of the lid margins. Treatment is the excision of the adhesions between lid margins.

questions.text: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of rupture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture. It usually occurs at the insertion of rectus muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.
